p: Similarly, our finding of higher HIV prevalence among synthetic drug users (10.6% compared to 6.0% among non-users) and 2-fold greater odds of HIV infection among synthetic drug users is also supported by the existing literature. A 2009 study among MSM in Changsha (n = 826) found HIV prevalence of 19% among users versus 11% among non-users and 2-fold greater odds of HIV infection among users [ 19]. In a 2011 study in Shenyang (n = 625) HIV prevalence was higher among users (20% versus 7%) and users had 3.5-fold greater odds of HIV infection [ 20]. In a 2012 study in Beijing (n = 400) synthetic drug use was associated with 3-fold greater odds of HIV infection [ 16]. A seven-city study completed in 2013 (n = 3,830) found higher HIV prevalence among users compared to non-users (12% versus 8%) [ 15]. In its larger companion study (n = 4,496) conducted in the same seven cities by the same research team also in 2013, 2-fold higher odds of recent HIV infection was found among MSM who had used synthetic drugs in the prior 6 months [ 21]. Finally, in 2014, another study in Beijing (n = 3,588) also found synthetic drug use to be associated with greater odds of HIV infection [ 17].
